{{Infobox MLB player |name=Glenn Beckert |position=[[Second baseman]] |image= |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{birth date and age|1940|10|12}} |birth_place=[[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] |death_date= |debutdate=April 12 |debutyear=1965 |debutteam=Chicago Cubs |finaldate=April 27 |finalyear=1975 |finalteam=San Diego Padres |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.283 |stat2label=[[Hit (baseball)|Hits]] |stat2value=1,473 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=360 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> * [[Chicago Cubs]] ({{by|1965}}â{{by|1973}}) * [[San Diego Padres]] ({{by|1974}}â{{by|1975}}) |highlights=<nowiki></nowiki> * 4Ã [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] selection ([[1969 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1969]], [[1970 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1970]], [[1971 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1971]], [[1972 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1972]]) * [[Gold Glove Award]] winner (1968) }} '''Glenn Alfred Beckert''' (born October 12, {{by|1940}} in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]) is a former [[United States|American]] [[Professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player. He played in [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] as a [[second baseman]] for the [[Chicago Cubs]] for nine seasons from {{by|1965}} to {{by|1973}} before ending his career with the [[San Diego Padres]] in {{by|1975}}.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference">[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/beckegl01.shtml Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=beckegl01 Glenn Beckert at Baseball Almanac]</ref>
==Baseball career== Beckert was drafted from [[Allegheny College]] as an amateur [[free agent]] by the [[Boston Red Sox]] in {{by|1962}}, then selected by Chicago Cubs from Red Sox in the first-year [[Minor League baseball|minor league]] draft.<ref name="Glenn Beckert Trades and Transactions at Baseball Almanac">[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=beckegl01 Glenn Beckert Trades and Transactions at Baseball Almanac]</ref> He spent three years in the minors as a [[shortstop]], where he led the [[Pacific Coast League]] in [[putouts]] and [[Assist (baseball)|assists]] in {{by|1964}}.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at The Baseball Library">[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Glenn_Beckert_1940 Glenn Beckert at The Baseball Library]</ref> Following the sudden death of Cubs second baseman, [[Ken Hubbs]] in [[1964 Chicago Cubs season|1964]], the Cubs brought Beckert to the major leagues as their second baseman for the [[1965 Chicago Cubs season|1965]] season.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at The Baseball Library"/>
Beckert played nine seasons as the Cubs' second baseman.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference"/> During his entire Cub tenure, he played alongside shortstop [[Don Kessinger]].<ref name="Glenn Beckert at The Baseball Library"/> Beckert led the [[National League]] in assists during his rookie year, and went on to become a four-time [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]].<ref name="Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference"/> He was a tough batter, leading the league five times in fewest [[strikeout]]s per [[at bat]]s.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at The Baseball Library"/> In [[1968 Chicago Cubs season|1968]], he led the league in [[Run (baseball)|runs]] and won the National League [[Gold Glove Award]] for second baseman.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1968-batting-leaders.shtml 1968 National League Batting Leaders at Baseball Reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1968 1968 National League Gold Glove Award winners at Baseball Reference]</ref> He had his best offensive season in [[1971 Chicago Cubs season|1971]] when he had a .342 [[batting average]] to finish third in the National League batting championship behind [[Joe Torre]] and [[Ralph Garr]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1971-batting-leaders.shtml 1971 National League Batting Leaders at Baseball Reference]</ref>
After the [[1973 Chicago Cubs season|1973]] season, he was traded along with [[Bobby Fenwick]] to the [[San Diego Padres]] for [[Jerry Morales]].<ref name="Glenn Beckert Trades and Transactions at Baseball Almanac"/> Beckert was a [[Utility player|utility]] [[infielder]] and [[pinch hitter]] with the Padres before being released in April [[1975 San Diego Padres season|1975]]. He is an inductee in the [[Chicagoland Sports Hall of Fame]].<ref>[http://www.clshf.com/hall_of_fame.htm Chicagoland Sports Hall of Fame]</ref>
==Career statistics== In an 11 year career, Beckert played in 1,320 [[Games played|games]], accumulating 1,473 [[Hit (baseball)|hits]] in 5,208 [[at bats]] for a .283 career batting average along with 22 home runs and 360 runs batted in.<ref name="Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference"/> He posted a .973 career [[fielding percentage]].<ref name="Glenn Beckert at Baseball Reference"/>
